awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Professional Preparation of Underrepresented Minority PhD's and Post-Docs for a Career in Engineering Academia
awd_abstract_narration:
The National Science Foundation, U.S. Department of Higher Education, and department administrators from universities across the country agree that increasing underrepresented populations in STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) fields is an important national need.  Most of the recent activities to rectify the deficiency of underrepresented populations in STEM disciplines have focused on initiatives from grade school to undergraduate college degrees (K-16).  These initiatives have made significant advances to enhancing the diversity of the US work force, however they have had minimal effect on the number of graduating PhD students entering professional positions as faculty in academic fields.  The lack of faculty diversification is alarming, considering that the primary sustainable method for developing future college-educated generations is a diverse STEM faculty. The goal of this collaborative project led by the University of Akron, in partnership with Mississippi State University and the University of Houston, is to increase the participation of underrepresented populations in engineering that pursue academic careers.  Providing participants with additional training in STEM education will yield more prepared engineering educators, which will lead to better-equipped engineers entering the workforce.  Similarly, affording additional skills to obtain research funding will assist with participants' ability to succeed at all stages of their careers.  An increase in underrepresented faculty could have a long-term sustainable impact on increasing the number of underrepresented populations that enter and are retained in engineering disciplines by providing academic role models/mentors.  The research component of this study will add to the national knowledge based on issues of career progression and inform practices on training doctoral students and postdoctoral associates. 

The proposed project builds upon the findings of the investigators 1.5 day workshops that focused on preparing PhD and postdoctoral trainees for academia.  Our findings, which supported previous outcomes, determined that most new faculty members, whether they had postdoctoral training or not, were not adequately prepared for academia.  The proposed project will provide expanded, intensive professional preparation for PhD and postdoctoral students through a series of two-week intensive summer professional preparation courses in conjunction with year-long activities to offer practical hands-one training in the areas of teaching and research.  Participants will be provided an opportunity to write a travel proposal to receive funds to meet with a federal grant coordinator or attend an educational/technical conference.  Each year the approach will be implemented and hosted at one of the collaborating institutions with participants recruited from the host university, institutions within a 200 mile radius, as well as a two from each of the collaborating institutions.  This effort has potential to significantly increase the numbers of underrepresented populations in engineering fields that pursue academic careers.

por.por_cntn:
The lack of diversity in engineering academia is a critical issue. In 2021, less than 20% of all engineering faculty positions were held by women. The percentages were even lower for Hispanic and African American engineering faculty, at 4% and 3% respectively. The goal of this collaborative project was to increase the participation and success of underrepresented populations in engineering academia.

Intellectual Merit

The findings from this project aided in advancing the national dialogue about how best to prepare future engineering faculty. Specifically, the findings highlighted the importance of engaging potential engineering faculty in STEM education teaching and learning and what knowledge, skills, and dispositions are essential in developing engineering faculty who will prepare future generations of STEM workers. Our work expands the current literature by clarifying the impact of a highly structured professional development program (the Advancing Careers in Academics with Diversity Education and Mentorship in Engineering (ACADEME) workshop) on engineering doctoral students who were near completion of the doctoral degree, those who completed the doctoral degree, and those in post-doctoral positons who expressed interests in pursuing careers in engineering academics. Further, it provided a clearer indication of the mentoring needs of new engineering faculty who are members of underrepresented populations and how such mentoring might lead to their persistence in engineering academia.

Broader Impacts

This project has impacted the field of engineering academics significantly. Sixteen of the ACADEME participants reported that they had successfully secured tenure track teaching positions by the end of the project. A total of three 2-week summer ACADEME workshops were held, one at each of the collaborating institutions and included 63 participants (i.e., doctoral students or postdoctoral fellows) overall.  During the first workshop held in summer 2017 at The University of Akron, there were 13 PhD participants, recruited primarily from the same geographical region and collaborating institutions.  However, with improved advertising and word-of-mouth from former participants, as well as expanding participation to postdocs, participation nearly doubled for the next two workshops held in summer 2018 at University of Houston and in summer 2019 at Mississippi State University.  Over the course of the project, 17 travel grants were awarded to support travel to technical and research conferences. Findings revealed that the year-long mentoring activities were beneficial in assisting participants in continued growth and development beyond the initial summer workshop.  Additionally, the participants agreed or strongly agreed that the program prepared them for the responsibilities and expectations to succeed in academic positions. These results demonstrated that the project was completed successfully.
